item.name: Acquire
item.comment: My favorite economic game. Sleek design and engaging game play make this a true classic. I own the 3M bookshelf game version.

item.name: Age of Conan: The Strategy Board Game
All Wound Up
item.comment: Couldn't resist the cool-looking wind-up zombies, although the game-play doesn't live up to the eye-candy factor.

item.name: Americana Golf Game
item.comment: Extremely bland and boring.

item.name: Ancient & Medieval Wargaming
item.comment: A solid and very approachable set of miniature wargame rules that play in a short timeframe and simulate the ancient & medieval periods fairly well. The army lists are nicely done. The book includes enough historical background to keep things interesting without becoming a boring history lesson. Those looking for more tactical depth and chrome will be disappointed, but if you like your wargames rules light and fast this fits the bill. Great work by Neil Thomas.

item.name: Apples to Apples
item.comment: Okay, but overly simple for my tastes. Good family game or light party game.

item.name: Backgammon
item.comment: A classic abstract game, but just never piqued my interest all that much.

item.name: Balderdash
item.comment: With a light-hearted group, this is one of the best ways to spend 60-90 minutes laughing your ass off. Not too great with strangers or overly serious gamers.

item.name: Battle Cry
item.comment: The most rules-light of the Commands & Colors series of wargames and probably the most luck heavy. Battle Cry does a nice job of simulating Civil War battles with a minimum of rules, and you can play in game in 45 minutes, which lends itself well to playing multiple scenarios in an evening, and swapping sides with your opponent to play both North and South. Lots of fun.

item.name: Battleball
item.comment: Awesome looking football figures. Will hopefully get to try this out some day!

item.name: BattleLore: The Hundred Years' War – Crossbows & Polearms
Battles With Model Soldiers
item.comment: For those who like collecting and reading old, classic miniature wargame books for a taste of nostalgia and a glimpse into the past (circa 1960's & 70's), this is a quick, enjoyable read. You can't go wrong with Featherstone. But to be truthful, there's no really deep takeaway ideas from this book.

item.name: Battlestorm
item.comment: Convulted mess of a wargames rulebook with an ugly layout.

item.name: Battue: Storm of the Horse Lords
De Bellis Antiquitatis
item.comment: The appeal here is ultra-fast playing time for a miniatures wargame, the small number of figures required for a mass-battle game, the ability to use any ancients/medievals models you have, and a very complete rules-set that's jam-packed with army lists. However, the rules writing borders on incomprehensible at times and the combat is fairly bland. I still don't understand why this is the most popular set of ancients rules on the planet. Odd.

item.name: De Bellis Multitudinis
item.comment: Takes DBA and makes it more rules-heavy and longer playing, but not any more fun. Pass.

item.name: Big City
item.comment: Got this in a BGG trade. Anxious to play this for the first time. The components look cool and the game-play sounds interesting.

item.name: Blue Line Hockey
item.comment: I love hockey, but this bland 3M game fails to capture the excitement, fast pace, and rough & tumble aspects of the sport.

item.name: Bowl Bound
item.comment: A very solid simulation of college football, with plenty of strategic play calling. Good for folks who enjoy nostalgic teams from the 60's and 70's, but it's appeal has waned and it has languished on my game shelf for many years now.

item.name: Breakthru
item.comment: A fun, little abstract game from 3M that I played as a teen, but it does nothing to get me excited to play it again.

item.name: Ca$h 'n Gun$
item.comment: How can you not laugh while pointing foam guns at each other and carrying out negotiations over the loot-pile using your cheesiest mobster accent? Quick-playing and lots of goofy fun.

item.name: Carcassonne
item.comment: A pretty nice intro-game for non-gamers which looks great once the entire build-as-you-go map is laid out. Easy to grasp rules, except for the overly confusing farmer scoring. Maybe I need to play this more, but the strategy just doesn't excite me enough.

item.name: Chaos Marauders
item.comment: Simple rules and somewhat fun, light card-laying game, especially for fans of orcs, but really nothing spectacular.

item.name: Chess
item.comment: A true classic, but I never wanted to devote my life to mastering it.

item.name: Condottiere
item.comment: Just acquired the older Eurogames big-box version with the big map and neat Tarot style playing cards. Looking forward to getting this one to the table.

item.name: Cosmic Encounter
item.comment: Have the old West End Games version
item.conditiontext: West End Games version, great condition

item.name: Crucible: Conquest of the Final Realm
Cutthroat Caverns
item.comment: A wild and wooly game which mixes cooperative play with loads of back-stabbing. The monsters you're trying to kill are varied and often innovative, the card-art is terrific, and the table-talk this game elicits is a hoot. Not recommended for an overly serious or sensitive gaming group, but for players who enjoy a romp it doesn't get much better than this.

item.name: Cutthroat Caverns: Deeper & Darker
item.comment: Takes a great game and ramps up the replayability factor.

item.name: Cyclades
item.comment: Fantastic game. Truly thematic, full of strategy, but with enough unexpected twists and turns to keep things exciting and not overly predictable. And the miniatures are flat-out terrific -- especially the monsters. One of my favorite games.

item.name: Dark Tower
item.comment: Without the tower, this game wouldn't be on anyone's radar. In fact, the game-play is on the boring side. But there's something geeky-cool about that whirring, beeping black overlord that salvages the game and makes it fun to break out on occasion.

item.name: Diplomacy
item.comment: There are many other things I enjoy doing a whole heckuva lot more than pissing off my friends for 6 hours. Blech.

item.name: Domaine
item.comment: An elegantly designed strategy game that's full of simple, yet interesting decisions. Scales really well and fits the theme (expanding your kingdom) quite nicely. My favorite Euro game.

item.name: Dragon's Gold
item.comment: I need to play this one more, but it's a fun negotiating-against-the-clock game with rules that are fairly easy to grasp even for non-gamers. Also like the card-art.

item.name: Drakon (third edition)
item.comment: Elegant, fast-playing, tactical and strategic, screw-your-neighbor, escape from the dungeon fun. Love it!

item.name: Featherstone's Complete Wargaming
item.comment: Classic wargaming book by Don Featherstone, covers a lot of ground. Despite its old school nature, it contains some good ideas to gets your creative juices flowing.

item.name: Feudal
item.comment: One of my all-time faves. This underrated 3M bookshelf classic can be best defined as a combination of Chess with simple Skirmish Wargaming rules. The pieces are fantastic, and it's easy to combine two sets for a bigger game. Best played with 2 players.

item.name: The Games of War: A Treasury of Rules for Battles with Toy Soldiers, Ships and Planes
Heroscape Expansion Set: Crest of the Valkyrie (Flagbearer series)
Heroscape Expansion Set: Dawn of Darkness
Heroscape Expansion Set: Defenders of Kinsland
Heroscape Expansion Set: Fields of Valor
Heroscape Expansion Set: Road to the Forgotten Forest
Heroscape Master Set: Battle for the Underdark
Heroscape Master Set: Rise of the Valkyrie
item.comment:
Simple skirmish battle rules, yet not simplistic. The combination of the elegant order system and combat system, the mix of squads vs heroes, special powers that make the tactical decisions fun & interesting, a variety of soliders from all time periods which oozes theme, and the inclusion of glyphs to add twists/objectives to the game, all result in a terrific game play experience.
And for gamers who love "bits", the Rise of the Valkyrie set contains the best components of any game under $75 that I've ever found in my life. Simply astounding value for the money. This is the best of all the HeroScape master sets by far.
There isn't a better skirmish game in a box. BRILLIANT!

item.name: Heroscape Master Set: Swarm of the Marro
Last Night on Earth: The Zombie Game
Lord of the Rings: The Confrontation (Deluxe Edition)
item.comment: The hobby-gamers version of Stratego, chock-full of Lord of the Rings flavor and elegant mechanics. PERFECT!

item.name: NHL Strategy
item.comment: One of my earliest forays into sports simulations as a young kid and fledgling Flyers fan, this is a fantastic, well-designed NHL hockey game. During its hey-day, I would have rated this a 9, but with no desire to play it any more my rating has dropped to a still solid 8.

item.name: Pass the Pigs
item.comment: Yahtzee with cute little pig dice. Tossing pigs is fun for a short time, but the shine wears off after awhile.

item.name: Paydirt
item.comment: My version is called Sports Illustrated Football.

item.name: Richard III: The Wars of the Roses
Rod Hockey
item.comment: Own a STIGA table hockey set. Need to start a league!

item.name: Setting up a Wargames Campaign
item.comment: Tony Bath classic. Very DEEP and definitely not light reading, but bursting with ideas for wargame campaign designers.

item.name: Slapshot
item.comment: Dead simple, fast-playing, throw 'em down, laughter-inducing, light-hearted fun for hockey fans. Best enjoyed when playing a series of connected games. A beer & pretzels classic.

item.name: Statis Pro Baseball
item.comment: My favorite game of all-time. Played this to death as a teenager with my best friends, drafting our own custom-built teams and playing out mini-seasons. Smooth-flowing game mechanics, enough strategy to suit my tastes, the ability to mix & match player cards to build your own fantasy teams, and relatively quick playing times (40-60 mins) make this a stellar game for the serious baseball fan.

item.name: Stocks & Bonds
item.comment: My Dad, Mom, brother Joey, and I used to play this back in the 1970's. The wild swings of the stock market used to make for exciting finishes. This was also a game which my Dad enjoyed, and that adds a certain fond nostalgia factor to it for me.

item.name: Strandhogg
item.comment: No longer need this now that I own SAGA.

item.name: Tactica: An Historical Approach to Ancient Wargaming
Talisman
item.comment: Definitely feels like a heroic fantasy quest, with plenty of color, random elements, and twists & turns. I played this a fair amount back in the day. The downside is that it can take too long to play for something that's more of a luck-fest than a true strategy game.

item.name: Through the Desert
item.comment: Colorful Knizia abstract that satisfies my "thinky" side while not taking too long to play. Love those candy-colored camels!

item.name: Ticket to Ride
item.comment: The perfect family game, and a true classic. It's intuitive, has good-looking map/cards/train-pieces, provides for solid strategic play while not being needlessly complex, and doesn't take overly long to get to a conclusion. Should be in every gamers collection.

item.name: Trivial Pursuit: All Star Sports Edition
War Games Rules 3000 BC to 1485 AD
Warhammer
item.comment: 3rd Edition is loaded with really cool stuff, and contains all the army lists in one book. Warhammer has the best background fluff of any fantasy wargame and is tremendously colorful (the painted models in the book are quite inspirational), but its game-mechanics are fiddly and sometimes clunky, and luck can often be a more important factor than smart generalship.

item.name: Wings of War: Famous Aces
item.comment: My rating for this game includes the nicely painted miniature bi-planes.

item.name: Wings of War: Top Fighters Booster Pack
